title: AutoFill promotes toxicity
body:
People get put in roles they cant play basically get a free loss, they get salty, and the next game it increases their likelyhood of flaming. Autofill is not useful, im in silver and i would happily wait 20 minutes if i could have a role i could play. Im sure its useful in high elo for reducing que time but i would highly value quality over quantity. Discuss.

Edit#1: Was tilted off my face when i wrote this. Alright anyone got the pros of autofill (except lower que times)? seems like only a pain to me and tilts me sideways. Also is autofill a relic of the old system from 2 seasons ago? Should it be removed for low elo? Maybe we could add a system that suggests champs for the autofill role? Sure it wont help higher elo people but for us plebs it would be much appreciated.

replies.body:
As a quick addition to what Sesshomaru has said about the why. Autofill exists for a reason. You say you'd be happy to wait 20 minutes for a queue, but would you be happy to wait an hour? Maybe even longer? In lower elo the saturation of support (and sometimes bot) players is just too low once you combine it with the small ranked population we have on OCE.

It's a delicate balance between how long a wait is acceptable before it creates a greater negative experience than the positive of getting your preferred role. People argued and argued for two ranked queues, and seem to be generally happy now that we have them, but the consequence of that is that autofill is going to be on pretty much all the time.

Even if you only learn one champion in your off roles (though preferably a less popular one so it doesn't get stolen or banned) you will gain some valuable experience. You don't have to carry every game, if you get autofilled, just do your best to hold your own, if you can't get fed then just stay even.
___
As for some support advice specifically (since it's mostly what you'll be filled as), I'd stay away from supports like Soraka or Sona. People seem to think they are brainless and easy supports but they really aren't. There is a lot of nuance there, and if you aren't experienced with them it is VERY easy to feed. As a support main myself, I can't tell you how many times someone has picked Sona as their "safe" pick and I've absolutely destroyed them. In the same vein a good Soraka is scary, but a bad one is damn near useless.

If you are good with skill shots Nami is a good choice, since she can do a bit of everything and is easy to learn (though hard to master). Lulu is also a good safe caster support with a lot of utility, but she's also harder to learn, and for the inexperienced I'd really recommend the sustain lane since it's easier to cover your mistakes with heals than shields. If you prefer tanks try someone like Braum or Leona with good scalings who have solid team utility even if they are behind. You want to go for the champs that can still be useful even if they are feeding.

And for love of all that is holy please do not pick Blitzcrank if you don't know how to play him. You can bet on that lucky hook ignite all you want but then you have nothing. He has very little to offer in team fights (the silence is strong but the duration isn't) and shines early, so if you can't deliver on that early promise then don't pick it. Really if you don't have communication in bot/a really damn good ADC you're just going to have a bad time.

If all else fails and you can't play any of the 'real' supports then just pick a CC heavy mid you know how to play like Syndra or something. It's not ideal, but it's better than playing someone you have no idea how to play. Just remember you'll be playing with a heavily limited mana pool and much less damage than you are used to.

> As a quick addition to what Sesshomaru has said about the why. Autofill exists for a reason. You say you'd be happy to wait 20 minutes for a queue, but would you be happy to wait an hour? Maybe even longer? In lower elo the saturation of support (and sometimes bot) players is just too low once you combine it with the small ranked population we have on OCE.

I have never had to wait more then 5 minutes for a ranked game ever, with or without autofill.

> It's a delicate balance between how long a wait is acceptable before it creates a greater negative experience than the positive of getting your preferred role.

Yet many people have admitted that they would still rather wait 10+ minutes to get the role they want?

> Even if you only learn one champion in your off roles (though preferably a less popular one so it doesn't get stolen or banned) you will gain some valuable experience. You don't have to carry every game, if you get autofilled, just do your best to hold your own, if you can't get fed then just stay even.

There is no point to this in bronze/silver because you have to basically carry every game.

> If all else fails and you can't play any of the 'real' supports then just pick a CC heavy mid you know how to play like Syndra or something. It's not ideal, but it's better than playing someone you have no idea how to play. Just remember you'll be playing with a heavily limited mana pool and much less damage than you are used to.

I can tell you now from experience that this is part of the reason autofill is toxic in the first place

Even as a support main I have had ranked queue times of 10~ minutes at times. There are a lot of variables, and they vary a lot from player to player. That said, it is certainly one of those things difficult to articulate without official stats. I'm confident that turning autofill off would cause big problems, but also don't have anything official to back it up other than words. The lack of visible stats is one of Riot's biggest failings imo tbh.

That said, you never experiencing a queue over 5 mins theoretically means it is working as it should, being on when it needs to be and off when it doesn't, even if I can't definitively prove that it is auto fill having this effect for you.
___
10+ minutes is a little different than an hour, which is usually why I pose such a question when people ask about autofill. It is a matter of degree, inconvenience vs reward.

___
I haven't been in Bronze for long so I can't really comment there, but in silver certainly there were plenty of people that got away with going even, the trouble was them having to learn how to play safe to actually stay even instead of snowballing the wrong way. It seems to be something much more uncommon there. I imagine it's an experience and perspective thing, but if you are willing to learn then that's what matters right? It's the best you can do in such circumstances.
___
Maybe it's my support mindset, but if I was ADC I'd much rather have my support on someone they knew how to play, than a real support they've never played before. I did say if all else fails. It's hardly ideal, but ultimately a comfort pick is better than a pick you can't play.
I still love how all the uneducated retards downvote my posts because they don't know what constructive criticism is.

Your criticism isn't constructive you complain about everything.

And part of constructive criticism is offering ideas. For example "im. It sure if that is the right keystone to take. Maybe try this one it should make you able to x better"

You have the criticism part down pat but in no way is it constructive

Well in this case at the very least it was. He provided feedback on my discussion, how he saw it. It might have been short but he hit all the points he wanted, and I had adequate information on his perspective to form a response to it. Disagreeing is not the same as complaining. It's a rather thin grey line between them but I wouldn't call his response not constructive.

I made some points, he made some points about where he disagreed. It isn't super in depth or anything but that doesn't mean it isn't constructive, or at the very least valid discussion.

100% agree it's valid discussion but I'm still not sure it's constructive criticism. Your also probably right on the disagreement vs complaint front, that's my bad.  

And while I agree it's a thin line between the two I still feel his falls on the side of just criticism. Which is fine there's nothing wrong with criticism. I just felt it was a bit rich of him to call it constructive while offering no soloutions and calling others uneducated retards.

You have a good point, and there's really no excuse for the retard comment, but as long as there is valid discussion and he doesn't continue with such comments I won't remove anything, but I must admit to being curious about your opinion on that one. I really would like more community feedback on moderation standards.

Sorry had indoor soccer tonight. I hesitate to say it's fine as it was a uncalled for comment but I think your current option is probably the best. 

The line between acceptable and unacceptable can often be very thin and has a nasty habit of moving.  Overall I think you guys are doing a good job. 

I think like comments like the one above aren't cool and probably cross the line. But personally I'm not going to take it to heart. And I have a feeling being to aggressive with removing said comments will probably encourage a certain sub set of the board population and end up with a lot of abuse directed at you guys. 

So tldr your doing a pretty good job at a difficult task. 
Perhaps offer a warning when you guys think someone is crossing or is close to crossing the line?

Does that help?

We usually issue a warning with the content removal, and we can ban/temp ban from boards though we only do so rarely. Most people just get stuff removed indefinitely, so long as it isn't excessive in severity or volume.

I have to agree with you about being too aggressive, it promotes the wrong sort of community, and while I don't think comments like his are ok, as you seem to understand removing such things can have their own set of problems, though I don't think that is necessarily the case here.

In this case I made the decision to leave it since he got some public feedback for his behaviour, which I think in a lot of ways is more valuable, especially since the comment was only vaguely targeted and rather mundane as insults go.

Thanks for the insight :)
I'm trying to defend you here but calling the nebulous 'they' retards doesn't do you any favours.

Sorry I just really hate some of the children on these boards, yet alone children on the internet in general. Not referring specifically to "young people" but to anyone who thinks they're intelligent because their age surpasses 18 and they're automatically more intelligent then anyone under the age of 18.

Believe me I understand and share your frustration with the narcissists and the hypocrites and the entitled arrogants etc etc, but it is for that very reason that we have to be better than them. Doesn't always work of course, all we can do is our best.

Remember that there are many reasons to downvote a post. Many do so simply out of disagreement rather than antagonism.

Great advice! 

Especially with regards to Sona and Soraka, those two are kind of seen as the poster-children for "Support". 
So they are the first champs that come to mind when you are unfamiliar with support and have to choose one on the spot.

Personally when I get autofilled, Leona is my usual go-to girl. Because as much as I love Taric, he is too difficult and situational for an on the spot pick when I haven't had any recent practice with him, and with an ADC I'm not used to. 
And like you say, because of her CC, Leona doesn't get behind as much as other more scaling dependent champs can do.
She can even still be useful as just a meat-shield.

Just remember, if you're not picking Zed, you're already doing better than some I've had the pleasure of encountering. :P

There's a lot of misconceptions about support being easy, and I can't say it doesn't bother me. Just because we don't have to micromanage CS doesn't mean it's easy, we have to juggle aggro, maintain a much greater degree of map awareness, pick and choose opportunities for pokes and engages, know where to be to do what, position in team fights to be able to support as many people as possible and so on and so on. It's different, but it's certainly not easy :P Easy to learn perhaps, but difficult to master.
Thanks this was really helpful, i might spam lulu games in normals, try to get decent with her.

Lulu is a lot of fun :) and a great flex pick too, she can mid and top if you want her to. 

She's got it all, heals (R), shields (E), knockups (R), full disables (W), speed boosts (W), slows (Q), vision reveal-y (E) and plenty of early and reliable harass damage (E+Q combo). Probably the most well rounded support there is. Not that she's always going to be the best pick, but certainly she's a solid one to pick up if you want to learn just one good champion for support.

I agree with Aidan7787

People forget that it used to be pick order that decided roles, and you had a much much slimmer chance of getting your preferred role, and no one minded at all. While now, you're almost guaranteed one of 2 preferred roles, and everyone freaks out on the odd occasion they have to go support.
it makes no sense.

My only concern with the new system _(which is not actually with the system itself, but how the players use the system)_ is that everyone only needs to learn 2 roles, so they do (cos theyre lazy), and they get very very good at those 2 roles (becasue thats all they ever play). Then they get autofilled, and have no clue what they're doing because they haven't practiced that role. But the people they're up against **are** in their preferred role (and remember this one of the only 2 roles they ever play). So you get a lvl 7 Thresh with 1,000,000 mastery points, against a first time Sona, and the game quickly spirals out of control.

In my opinion, the new system is great, you go into ranked knowing that you will most likely be able to perform at your best, and be ranked according to what youre good at playing. However because everyone only ever masters 2 roles, the difficulty of ranked as a whole rises up, becasue everyone is playing what they're good at, and so on the odd occasion you down get your role, it is a lot lot harder for you and your team.

This is of course solved simply by everyone just spending a little bit of time practicing other roles _(but good luck trying to pry 12 year olds away from Yasuo and Lee....)_

So really its not the system but the players that are at fault here.

I understand the old system that was in place but wasnt that removed to reduce toxicity? Imo the auto fill brings some of that toxicity back, what would be the harm in removing autofil in low elos? or having an option to turn it off at the cost of longer que times, or even a low priority que? Maybe incentivise having fill as your role? Have a special banner maybe, if you win a certain amount of games with fill as your role you get an icon/wardskin/border/ribbon that shows you can play a multitude of positions. I dont know im just putting ideas out there.

I agree that there could be more creative and constructive ways of incentivising players to fill. And I'm sure earning a banner or other reward for filling would be a much more preferable solution to autofill for most players.

However there must be a line drawn somewhere, while positive incentive is powerful, you can't start rewarding people for things they should kinda just be doing anyway, without having to be asked.

Its like if you gave your dog a treat for going to the toilet outside instead of inside, yes its nice for the dog, but really it's kinda expected to go to the toilet outside anyway, and shouldn't be rewarded for performing such a basic task.
It makes rewarding it for actually doing something good (like a trick) less effective.

My guess is that Riot are saving positive incentives for player behaviour related issues.
If you got free skins and icons and banners for everything, then it would make the skins you get for being nice to people less of a treat, and therefore people wouldn't work as hard to get them.

That'd be my guess, at least. 

But, if you can come up with a unique solution that Riot hasn't thought of, I'm sure they are listening out!

The honor system on a whole feels not very rewarding, i mean the only good rewards are end of season. Maybe they could give positive players, a recall effect, as well as that little ribbon on the loading screen that everyone tabs out of.  I mean i am not a very good person when it comes to flaming, and i would be lying if i didnt say i havent had my super angry smash keyoard in game rant calling everyone to go... and i havnt had any punishment, im pretty sure i deserve it but ive never gotten a warning or any form of punishment, maybe they could give players a free champ shard that works as a champ permanent for a level 6 or 7 upgrade, wouldnt give them the s but it would save them from getting the blue essence, maybe they could get a 3rd of a champ reroll, like a blank space that fills in one slot for the reroll of three skin shards and you could get one every so many honorable opponents or teamwork with the current modifiers attached to the procurement of these points. I dont know ive never made a game, and im sleep deprived. Good talk. Its people like you that give me faith in the league communty.

I agree the honour system isn't very fulfilling. 
Especially when you earn multiple ribbons, _(ive earned all of the ribbons twice now, once on the NA server and then again on OCE, and yet only the most recent one is ever seen.)_
So if you want a blue ribbon, you just have to pray that you earn them in the right order so that blue is the last one.
But they are working on improving it as shown here:

http://nexus.leagueoflegends.com/2017/03/riot-pls-2017-dev-plans/

That looks interesting indeed. ^^

You realise like 2 seasons ago you had to play all roles.... But on autofill all you can do is learn a champ or two in each role so when you get autofilled you can play. There is more chance someone will get salty on the other team than on your team if you are happy playing each role. Just try and be supportive tell them to sit back, play safe and then you try and get fed. I dont love autofill either but I play my Zilean support when i have to

I don't really have a problem with it. Like the other guys said it wasn't that long ago you couldn't choose roles at all. It isn't that hard to pick up one or two champions in each role. There's even some champions that can fit into multiples. Like Annie who's really easy to play and is pretty much always useful because of her CC. 

Personally I don't really mind to much if I get Autofilled I main Top lane but I can play a couple of adcs, mids and supps. Recently I've actually been winning more games out of my second role ADC than my primary. The only role I'm not super confident in is jungle. Mostly cause I struggle with the jungle pathing. In the cases I get filled in that role I politely ask if anyone wants to swap. If they do great, if they don't I just take someone tanky and with CC like Zac. 

It doesn't take long to learn one or two champions in other roles and chances are it will give you a much better understanding of the game.
